title: Quiz 3: Environmental Health
description: Diploma in Community Health - Department of Health Promotion and Community Health

questions.question: We talk of health in terms of
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C. Dimensions Explanation: Health is multidimensional, typically described in terms of physical, mental, social, spiritual, emotional, and vocational dimensions (as implied by the WHO definition).

questions.question: Why has human faeces become so much concern for environmental health practitioners

options.text: It has bad odour and makes the environment dirty
Everyone defecates hence it indicates the adequate and successful digestion process

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B. It’s a risk factor Explanation: Human faeces is a primary vehicle for the transmission of pathogenic microorganisms (bacteria, viruses, parasites) causing fecal-oral diseases like cholera, typhoid, and dysentery.

questions.question: Which of the following statement is correct about sanitation and hygiene

options.text: Are addressed by health care experts only

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C. Are complementary Explanation: Sanitation (infrastructure/management of waste) and Hygiene (behaviors/practices like handwashing) work together to prevent disease. You need both to effectively break the chain of infection.

questions.question: Sanitation ladder addresses;

options.text: Sanitation challenges and approaches to address them as per your wish

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D. Steps in the ladder accordingly Explanation: The "Sanitation Ladder" is a concept used (e.g., by WHO/JMP) to describe the progression of service levels from open defecation (bottom) to unimproved, limited, basic, and finally safely managed services (top).

questions.question: The principles of waste optimization entails _________
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C. Reduce, Reuse and Recovery Explanation: Waste management hierarchies emphasize the "3 Rs" (Reduce, Reuse, Recycle) and Recovery (energy/materials) before disposal. Option C represents these optimization steps.

questions.question: Water pollutants are broadly grouped into;
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C. 3 Explanation: Water pollutants are commonly classified into three broad categories: Biological agents (pathogens), Chemical agents (organic/inorganic), and Physical agents (heat, suspended solids/turbidity).

questions.question: Which one is not a water based disease
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A. Soil transmitted helminths Explanation: STH: Transmitted via soil (geo-helminths), not water based. Cholera: Water-borne (fecal-oral via water). Dracunculiasis: Water-based (host/vector lives in water). Malaria: Water-related insect vector (mosquito breeds in water).

questions.question: Which one is not a sources of indoor air pollution
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A. H₂O Explanation: Water vapor (H₂O) is a natural component of air and not considered a pollutant. NO₂ (Nitrogen Dioxide), SO₂ (Sulfur Dioxide), and CO (Carbon Monoxide) are harmful indoor air pollutants often from combustion.

questions.question: Reduction in temperatures is best used to prevent which kind of food spoilage
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C. Microbial spoilage Explanation: Low temperatures (refrigeration/freezing) slow down the growth and reproduction of bacteria, molds, and yeasts (microorganisms) that cause food spoilage.

questions.question: Why menstrual hygiene

options.text: A measure to promote dignity and promote health
The female vagina has a large surface area

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B. A measure to promote dignity and promote health Explanation: Good menstrual hygiene management is essential to prevent urogenital infections (health) and ensure women and girls can participate in daily life with confidence and dignity.

questions.question: The components of healthful housing entails all the following except
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B. Ceramic roofing materials Explanation: Healthful housing focuses on principles like adequate ventilation, protection against vectors, prevention of overcrowding (space/density), and sanitary facilities. The specific type of roofing material (e.g., ceramic) is an aesthetic/structural choice, not a fundamental health requirement, provided it offers protection from weather.

questions.question: Standard definition of health was ratified by WHO in which year?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B. 1948 Explanation: The WHO Constitution, containing the famous definition of health, came into force on April 7, 1948.

questions.question: The main global contributing factors to greenhouse-gas emissions are
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A. Electricity production and transportation Explanation: The energy sector (electricity and heat production) and the transportation sector are the largest contributors to global greenhouse gas emissions (burning fossil fuels).

questions.question: Which of the following is a biotic component of the ecosystem
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C. Fungi Explanation: Biotic components are the living parts of an ecosystem (plants, animals, fungi, bacteria). Temperature, humidity, and sunlight are abiotic (non-living) components.

questions.question: Disease prevention strategies are divided into
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B. Levels Explanation: Prevention is classically categorized into three levels : Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary prevention.

questions.question: Soil Transmitted helminths always causes;
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C. Infestation Explanation: Helminths (worms) cause "infestation" rather than "infection" (which typically refers to micro-organisms like bacteria/viruses). While they lead to morbidity, "infestation" describes the biological state.

questions.question: Which one is not a step in health care waste management
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A. Commercially reusing the wastes Explanation: Health care waste is generally hazardous. Reusing it commercially (without proper, typically expensive and rare, sterilization for specific items) is dangerous and unethical. The standard steps are Segregation -> Collection -> Storage -> Transport -> Treatment -> Disposal.

questions.question: IEC a concept in environmental health education stands for
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C. Information Education and Communication Explanation: IEC represents the strategy of sharing information and educating communities to achieve desired health behaviors.

questions.question: Which of the terms best describe the components of healthful housing

options.text: Use of ceramic tiles for flooring
Two bedrooms and a dining space

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B. Adequate lighting and ventilation Explanation: Fundamental physiological requirements for healthful housing include proper lighting (to prevent eye strain/accidents) and ventilation (to remove indoor pollutants/heat).

questions.question: Which of the following groups of water sources are easier to protect from unauthorized access and contamination.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C. Wells, Springs and boreholes Explanation: Groundwater sources (wells, springs, boreholes) can be physically covered and protected at the source. Surface water sources (rivers, ponds, swamps) are open, extensive, and very difficult to fully protect from runoff and human/animal access.

questions.question: State any five risks and problems Associated with Solid wastes.
questions.explanation: It acts as media for the growth of microorganisms (pathogens). Attraction of vectors/arthropods such as houseflies and mosquitoes. Attraction of rodents and scavengers (rats, dogs) which can spread disease. Leachate from open dumps can contaminate ground and surface water sources. Can contaminate food supplies causing food-borne diseases. Hospital/pathological wastes are hazardous and potential disease carriers. Fire hazards (accidents/methane explosions). Nuisance: Bad odour, smoke, and aesthetic degradation (visual pollution). Physical discomfort: Sneezing, coughing from dust/smoke.

questions.question: Highlight the major sources of health care wastes.
questions.explanation: Hospitals (Public and Private). Veterinary clinics. Private clinics and dispensaries. Laboratories and research centers. Beauty parlors (sharps/skin piercing instruments). Pharmaceutical manufacturers/distributors (expired drugs). Blood banks and blood collection services. Specialized establishments: Nursing homes, mortuaries.

questions.question: State the five important pathogenic microorganisms transmitted by water.
questions.explanation: Salmonellae (causing Typhoid). Vibrios (causing Cholera). Shigellas (causing Dysentery). Brucella (causing Brucellosis - though often milk, can be water). Hepatitis A or E virus (causing Hepatitis). Note: The source also lists Anthrax and Ruam (Glanders) which are rarer but possible.

questions.question: State and briefly describe any two principles of healthful housing.
questions.explanation: Protection against communicable diseases: Ensuring adequate safe water supply, sanitary disposal of excreta, and prevention of vector breeding. Protection against injuries: Safe structural design, fire protection, and protection against electrical hazards. Prevention of poisonings and chronic diseases: Proper ventilation to remove indoor pollutants and safe building materials (no lead/asbestos). Reducing psychological and social stresses: Adequate space, privacy, and prevention of noise pollution.

questions.question: What is food safety? (5 Marks)
questions.explanation: i. Definition: Food safety is the protection of consumers from the risk of food poisoning and food-borne diseases. It covers all methods for destroying physical, chemical, and biological hazards in food to prevent illness, especially in vulnerable groups like children and the elderly. ii. Definitions of terms: Sterilization: Any process that eliminates, removes, kills, or deactivates all forms of life (microorganisms like fungi, bacteria, viruses) and other biological agents present in a specified region/surface/fluid. Contamination: The presence of harmful chemicals and microorganisms in food which can cause consumer illness. It can occur directly or indirectly through cross-contamination.

questions.question: State 5 factors that can promote menstrual hygiene. (5 Marks)
questions.explanation: Health education and awareness creation. Health promotion initiatives targeting girls and women. Good nutrition to support general health. Involving fathers and males in menstrual hygiene discussions to break taboos. Policy changes supporting menstrual hygiene (e.g., free sanitary pads in schools). Availability of sanitary facilities (clean water, soap, private disposal).

questions.question: Fill the table with the correct danger signs of the named diseases
questions.explanation: DISEASE DANGER SIGNS a) Malaria High fever b) Cholera Rice water diarrhoea c) Dysentery Bloody diarrhoea d) Typhoid Abdominal pain / Constipation e) Poliomyelitis Weak limbs / Flaccid paralysis

questions.question: Enumerate the 5 main vehicles of cross contamination. (5 marks)
questions.explanation: Hands (of food handlers). Cloths (wiping cloths, aprons). Equipment (knives, cutting boards, utensils). Hand Contact surfaces (door handles, taps). Food contact surfaces (tables, counters).

questions.question: Discuss the various aspects of human wastes that is important in the study of Environmental Health.
questions.explanation: Introduction: Human waste comprises primarily of feces and urine. Its proper management is critical in environmental health to prevent disease transmission and environmental degradation. 1. Health Risks Associated with Human Feces: Pathogen Transmission: Feces contain bacteria (Salmonella, Shigella), viruses (Polio, Hepatitis A), and parasites (Hookworm, Ascaris). Improper disposal leads to fecal-oral diseases. Contamination of Water Sources: Runoff from open defecation sites can pollute rivers and groundwater, causing outbreaks of Cholera and Typhoid. Food Contamination: Use of night soil (untreated feces) as fertilizer transmits helminths and pathogens to crops. 2. Environmental Impact: Aesthetics: Open defecation makes the environment unsightly and produces offensive odours. Vector Breeding: Feces attract flies which mechanically transfer pathogens to food (The 5 Fs: Faeces, Fluids, Fingers, Flies, Food). 3. Control Measures (Barriers): Primary Barrier: Safe disposal of feces (Sanitation). Use of latrines/toilets isolates feces from the environment. Secondary Barriers: Hand washing with soap, clean water supply, and washing fruits/vegetables. 4. Socio-Cultural Aspects: Taboos regarding sharing latrines (e.g., in-laws) can hinder sanitation usage. Privacy and dignity issues, especially for women and girls.

questions.question: Describe the HACCP principle as used in food hygiene and safety. (20 marks)
questions.explanation: Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point (HACCP) is a systematic, pro-active approach to food safety that focuses on preventing hazards rather than inspecting finished products. The Seven Principles of HACCP: Conduct a Hazard Analysis: Identify potential biological, chemical, or physical hazards at every stage of the process (growing to serving). Determine likelihood and severity. Determine Critical Control Points (CCPs): Identify the points in the process where control can be applied to prevent, eliminate, or reduce the hazard to an acceptable level (e.g., cooking temperature). Establish Critical Limits: Set maximum or minimum values (limits) for parameters like temperature or time at each CCP to distinguish safe from unsafe conditions (e.g., Cook chicken to 74°C). Establish Monitoring Procedures: Define how to measure the critical limits (Who, What, When, How). E.g., Using a thermometer to check soup temperature every 2 hours. Establish Corrective Actions: Decide what must be done if monitoring shows a critical limit has been reached or exceeded (e.g., Discard food, re-cook). Establish Verification Procedures: Activities (audits, testing) to confirm that the HACCP system is working effectively and is scientifically valid. Establish Record-Keeping and Documentation: Maintain proof of all procedures, monitoring logs, deviations, and corrective actions taken for traceability and legal defence.
